<mxfile host="app.diagrams.net" agent="Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.15; rv:131.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/131.0" version="24.7.17"> <diagram name="Page-1" id="D-NrUUmpyTxzQgRoT9al"> <mxGraphModel dx="2021" dy="738" grid="1" gridSize="10" guides="1" tooltips="1" connect="1" arrows="1" fold="1" page="1" pageScale="1" pageWidth="827" pageHeight="1169" math="0" shadow="0"> <root> <mxCell id="0" /> <mxCell id="1" parent="0" /> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-1" value="<b><font style="font-size: 16px;">Azure app services</font></b>" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="329" y="28" width="170" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-2" value="<table style="width: 99%;"><tbody><tr><td style="padding: 0;"><div><b><span>Run</span></b></div><div><span>Windows web apps</span></div><div><span>Linux web apps</span></div><div><span>Docker containers </span></div><div><span>Azure Functions</span></div><div><span>Logic apps (Standard) </span></div></td></tr></tbody></table><table style="width: 99%;"><tbody><tr><td style="padding: 0;"><div><b><span>Features</span></b></div><div><span>Win/Linux</span></div><div><span>Https based</span></div><div><span>Autoscaling</span></div><div><span>Load balancing</span></div><div><span>Improved security </span></div></td></tr></tbody></table><table style="width: 99%;"><tbody><tr><td style="padding: 0;"><div><b><span>Used for</span></b></div><div><span>Restful api's</span></div><div><span>Web apps</span></div><div><span>Mobile backend</span></div></td></tr></tbody></table><table style="width: 99%;"><tbody><tr><td style="padding: 0;"><div><b><span style="color:#1f1f1f">App service plan defines the compute resources</span></b></div><div><span style="color:#1f1f1f">Pricing tier</span></div><div><span style="color:#1f1f1f">OS</span></div><div><span style="color:#1f1f1f">Region</span></div><div><span style="color:#1f1f1f">Size of VM</span></div><div><span style="color:#1f1f1f">Number of Vm</span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="269" y="58" width="290" height="330" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-3" value="App service plan" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="294" y="420" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-4" value="<ul>
<li>Operating System (Windows, Linux)</li>
<li>Region (West US, East US, etc.)</li>
<li>Number of VM instances</li>
<li>Size of VM instances (Small, Medium, Large)</li>
<li>Pricing tier (Free, Shared, Basic, Standard, Premium, PremiumV2, PremiumV3, Isolated, IsolatedV2)</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="100" y="500" width="560" height="210" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-5" value="Pricing tier" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="230" y="738" width="80" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-6" value="<ul>
<li><strong>Shared compute</strong>: <strong>Free</strong> and <strong>Shared</strong>,
 the two base tiers, runs an app on the same Azure VM as other App 
Service apps, including apps of other customers. These tiers allocate 
CPU quotas to each app that runs on the shared resources, and the 
resources can't scale out.</li>
<li><strong>Dedicated compute</strong>: The <strong>Basic</strong>, <strong>Standard</strong>, <strong>Premium</strong>, <strong>PremiumV2</strong>, and <strong>PremiumV3</strong>
 tiers run apps on dedicated Azure VMs. Only apps in the same App 
Service plan share the same compute resources. The higher the tier, the 
more VM instances are available to you for scale-out.</li>
<li><strong>Isolated</strong>: The <strong>Isolated</strong> and <strong>IsolatedV2</strong>
 tiers run dedicated Azure VMs on dedicated Azure Virtual Networks. It 
provides network isolation on top of compute isolation to your apps. It 
provides the maximum scale-out capabilities.</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="69" y="790" width="490" height="270" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-7" value="Deployments " style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="269" y="1090" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-8" value="<ul>
<li><strong>Azure DevOps Services</strong>: You can push your code to 
Azure DevOps Services, build your code in the cloud, run the tests, 
generate a release from the code, and finally, push your code to an 
Azure Web App.</li>
<li><strong>GitHub</strong>: Azure supports automated deployment 
directly from GitHub. When you connect your GitHub repository to Azure 
for automated deployment, any changes you push to your production branch
 on GitHub are automatically deployed for you.</li>
<li><strong>Bitbucket</strong>: With its similarities to GitHub, you can configure an automated deployment with Bitbucket.</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="74" y="1169" width="560" height="230" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-9" value="Manual deployment" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="269" y="1440" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-10" value="<ul>
<li><strong>Git</strong>: App Service web apps feature a Git URL that 
you can add as a remote repository. Pushing to the remote repository 
deploys your app.</li>
<li><strong>CLI</strong>: <code>webapp up</code> is a feature of the <code>az</code> command-line interface that packages your app and deploys it. Unlike other deployment methods, <code>az webapp up</code> can create a new App Service web app for you if you haven't already created one.</li>
<li><strong>Zip deploy</strong>: Use <code>curl</code> or a similar HTTP utility to send a ZIP of your application files to App Service.</li>
<li><strong>FTP/S</strong>: FTP or FTPS is a traditional way of pushing your code to many hosting environments, including App Service.</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="49" y="1530" width="560" height="250" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-11" value="Deployment slots" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="270" y="1820" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-12" value="Whenever possible, use deployment slots when deploying a new production <br/>build. When using a Standard App Service Plan tier or better, you can <br/>deploy your app to a staging environment and then swap your staging and <br/>production slots. The swap operation warms up the necessary worker <br/>instances to match your production scale, thus eliminating downtime." style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="135" y="1890" width="390" height="80" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-13" value="Continuously deploy code" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="280" y="1980" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-14" value="If your project has designated branches for testing, QA, and staging, <br/>then each of those branches should be continuously deployed to a staging<br/> slot. This allows your stakeholders to easily assess and test the <br/>deployed branch." style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="164" y="2050" width="380" height="70" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-15" value="Continuously deploy container" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="280" y="2140" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-16" value="<p>For custom containers from Azure Container Registry or other 
container registries, deploy the image into a staging slot and swap into
 production to prevent downtime. The automation is more complex than 
code deployment because you must push the image to a container registry 
and update the image tag on the webapp.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Build and tag the image</strong>: As part of the build 
pipeline, tag the image with the git commit ID, timestamp, or other 
identifiable information. It’s best not to use the default “latest” tag.
 Otherwise, it’s difficult to trace back what code is currently 
deployed, which makes debugging far more difficult.</li>
<li><strong>Push the tagged image</strong>: Once the image is built and 
tagged, the pipeline pushes the image to our container registry. In the 
next step, the deployment slot will pull the tagged image from the 
container registry.</li>
<li><strong>Update the deployment slot with the new image tag</strong>: When this property is updated, the site will automatically restart and pull the new container image.</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="100" y="2220" width="560" height="350" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-17" value="Authentication" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="294" y="2580" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="t23GjzB4oMDSynpTIMgd-2" value="Authentication" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="294" y="2580" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-18" value="<ul>
<li>Azure App Service allows you to integrate various auth capabilities into your web app or API without implementing them yourself.</li>
<li>Auth is built directly into the platform and doesn’t require any particular language, SDK, security expertise, or code.</li>
<li>You can integrate with multiple login providers. For example, Microsoft Entra ID, Facebook, Google, X.</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="80" y="2670" width="560" height="180" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="t23GjzB4oMDSynpTIMgd-3" value="<ul>
<li>Azure App Service allows you to integrate various auth capabilities into your web app or API without implementing them yourself.</li>
<li>Auth is built directly into the platform and doesn’t require any particular language, SDK, security expertise, or code.</li>
<li>You can integrate with multiple login providers. For example, Microsoft Entra ID, Facebook, Google, X.</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="80" y="2670" width="560" height="180" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-19" value="<ul>
<li>Authenticates users and clients with the specified identity provider</li>
<li>Validates, stores, and refreshes OAuth tokens issued by the configured identity provider</li>
<li>Manages the authenticated session</li>
<li>Injects identity information into HTTP request headers</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="100" y="2830" width="500" height="170" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="t23GjzB4oMDSynpTIMgd-4" value="<ul>
<li>Authenticates users and clients with the specified identity provider</li>
<li>Validates, stores, and refreshes OAuth tokens issued by the configured identity provider</li>
<li>Manages the authenticated session</li>
<li>Injects identity information into HTTP request headers</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="100" y="2830" width="500" height="170" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="MfPjebhP18lG6qCuH9y4-20" value="Authentication flow" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="294" y="3020" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-1" value="<p>The authentication flow is the same for all providers, but differs 
depending on whether you want to sign in with the provider's SDK.</p>
<ul>
<li><p>Without provider SDK: The application delegates federated sign-in
 to App Service. This delegation is typically the case with browser 
apps, which can present the provider's login page to the user. The 
server code manages the sign-in process and is referred to as <em>server-directed flow</em> or <em>server flow</em>.</p>
</li>
<li><p>With provider SDK: The application signs users in to the provider
 manually and then submits the authentication token to App Service for 
validation. This is typically the case with browser-less apps, which 
can't present the provider's sign-in page to the user. The application 
code manages the sign-in process and is referred to as <em>client-directed flow</em> or <em>client flow</em>.
 This applies to REST APIs, Azure Functions, JavaScript browser clients,
 and native mobile apps that sign users in using the provider's SDK.</p>
</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="90" y="3100" width="560" height="410" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-2" value="Networking" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="290" y="3550" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-3" value="<p>The worker VMs are broken down in large part by the App Service 
plans. The Free, Shared, Basic, Standard, and Premium plans all use the 
same worker VM type. The PremiumV2 plan uses another VM type. PremiumV3 
uses yet another VM type. When you change the VM family, you get a 
different set of outbound addresses.</p>
<p>There are many addresses that are used for outbound calls. The 
outbound addresses used by your app for making outbound calls are listed
 in the properties for your app. These addresses are shared by all the 
apps running on the same worker VM family in the App Service deployment.
 If you want to see all the addresses that your app might use in a scale
 unit, there's a property called <code>possibleOutboundIpAddresses</code> that lists them.</p>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="130" y="3650" width="470" height="250" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-4" value="<pre class="has-inner-focus"><code class="lang-bash" data-author-content="cd html-docs-hello-world

az webapp up -g $resourceGroup -n $appName --html"><span>az webapp up -g <span class="hljs-variable">$resourceGroup</span> -n <span class="hljs-variable">$appName</span> --html</span></code></pre>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="145" y="3930" width="390" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-5" value="App settings" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="294" y="4040" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-6" value="App settings is a json env var which is passed to the app " style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="179" y="4128" width="320" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-7" value="<pre tabindex="0" aria-label="Horizontally scrollable code" role="group" class="has-inner-focus"><code data-author-content="az webapp config appsettings set --resource-group <group-name> --name <app-name> --settings key1=value1 key2=value2" class="lang-azurecli"><span><span class="hljs-keyword">az webapp config appsettings set </span><span class="hljs-parameter">--resource-group</span> <span class="hljs-string">&lt;group-name&gt;</span> <span class="hljs-parameter">--name</span> <span class="hljs-string">&lt;app-name&gt;</span> <span class="hljs-parameter">--settings</span> key1=value1 key2=value2</span></code></pre>" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="-23" y="4170" width="850" height="50" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-8" value="Path mapping" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;fontFamily=Helvetica;fontSize=11;fontColor=default;labelBackgroundColor=default;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="294" y="4240" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-9" value="In the <strong>Configuration &gt; Path mappings</strong> section you can configure handler mappings, and virtual application and directory mappings. The <strong>Path mappings</strong> page displays different options based on the OS type." style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="110" y="4330" width="560" height="70" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-10" value="Windows" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="85" y="4418" width="70" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <UserObject label="<p>or Windows apps, you can customize the IIS handler mappings and virtual applications and directories.</p>
<p>Handler mappings let you add custom script processors to handle 
requests for specific file extensions. To add a custom handler, select <strong>New handler mapping</strong>. Configure the handler as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Extension</strong>: The file extension you want to handle, such as *<em>.php</em> or <em>handler.fcgi</em>.</li>
<li><strong>Script processor</strong>: The absolute path of the script 
processor. Requests to files that match the file extension are processed
 by the script processor. Use the path <code>D:\home\site\wwwroot</code> to refer to your app's root directory.</li>
<li><strong>Arguments</strong>: Optional command-line arguments for the script processor.</li>
</ul>" link="<p>or Windows apps, you can customize the IIS handler mappings and virtual applications and directories.</p>
<p>Handler mappings let you add custom script processors to handle 
requests for specific file extensions. To add a custom handler, select <strong>New handler mapping</strong>. Configure the handler as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Extension</strong>: The file extension you want to handle, such as *<em>.php</em> or <em>handler.fcgi</em>.</li>
<li><strong>Script processor</strong>: The absolute path of the script 
processor. Requests to files that match the file extension are processed
 by the script processor. Use the path <code>D:\home\site\wwwroot</code> to refer to your app's root directory.</li>
<li><strong>Arguments</strong>: Optional command-line arguments for the script processor.</li>
</ul>" id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-11"> <mxCell style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="90" y="4460" width="560" height="350" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> </UserObject> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-12" value="Linux and containarized apps" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="30" y="4838" width="180" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-13" value="<p>ou can add custom storage for your containerized app. Containerized 
apps include all Linux apps and also the Windows and Linux custom 
containers running on App Service. Select <strong>New Azure Storage Mount</strong> and configure your custom storage as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Name</strong>: The display name.</li>
<li><strong>Configuration options</strong>: <strong>Basic</strong> or <strong>Advanced</strong>. Select <strong>Basic</strong> if the storage account isn't using service endpoints, private endpoints, or Azure Key Vault. Otherwise, select <strong>Advanced</strong>.</li>
<li><strong>Storage accounts</strong>: The storage account with the container you want.</li>
<li><strong>Storage type</strong>: <strong>Azure Blobs</strong> or <strong>Azure Files</strong>. Windows container apps only support Azure Files. Azure Blobs only supports read-only access.</li>
<li><strong>Storage container</strong>: For basic configuration, the container you want.</li>
<li><strong>Share name</strong>: For advanced configuration, the file share name.</li>
<li><strong>Access key</strong>: For advanced configuration, the access key.</li>
<li><strong>Mount path</strong>: The absolute path in your container to mount the custom storage.</li>
<li><strong>Deployment slot setting</strong>: When checked, the storage mount settings also apply to deployment slots.</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="40" y="4868" width="560" height="490" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-14" value="Error logging" style="rounded=0;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;strokeWidth=3;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="260" y="5420" width="120" height="60" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-15" value="Application logging" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="40" y="5488" width="120" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-16" value="Web server loging" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="49" y="5630" width="120" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-17" value="Detailed error messages" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="49" y="5740" width="150" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-18" value="Logs messages generated by your application code. The messages are 
generated by the web framework you choose, or from your application code
 directly using the standard logging pattern of your language. Each 
message is assigned one of the following categories: <strong>Critical</strong>, <strong>Error</strong>, <strong>Warning</strong>, <strong>Info</strong>, <strong>Debug</strong>, and <strong>Trace</strong>." style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="250" y="5500" width="560" height="100" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-19" value="Raw HTTP request data in the W3C extended log file format. Each log 
message includes data like the HTTP method, resource URI, client IP, 
client port, user agent, response code, and so on." style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="250" y="5630" width="410" height="70" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-20" value="Copies of the <em>.html</em> error pages that would have been sent to 
the client browser. For security reasons, detailed error pages shouldn't
 be sent to clients in production, but App Service can save the error 
page each time an application error occurs that has HTTP code 400 or 
greater." style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="250" y="5740" width="410" height="100" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-21" value="<table aria-label="Table 1" class="table"><tbody><tr><td>Failed request tracing</td></tr></tbody></table>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="60" y="5880" width="150" height="40" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-22" value="Detailed tracing information on failed requests, including a trace of 
the IIS components used to process the request and the time taken in 
each component. One folder is generated for each failed request, which 
contains the XML log file, and the XSL stylesheet to view the log file 
with." style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="250" y="5890" width="410" height="100" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-23" value="<table aria-label="Table 1" class="table"><tbody><tr><td>Deployment logging</td></tr></tbody></table>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="69" y="6040" width="150" height="40" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-24" value="Helps determine why a deployment failed. Deployment logging happens 
automatically and there are no configurable settings for deployment 
logging." style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="250" y="6040" width="410" height="70" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-25" value="Stream logs" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="155" y="6128" width="90" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-26" value="Before you stream logs in real time, enable the log type that you want. 
Any information written to files ending in .txt, .log, or .htm that are 
stored in the <code>/LogFiles</code> directory (<code>d:/home/logfiles</code>) is streamed by App Service." style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="50" y="6200" width="500" height="70" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-27" value="Access logs file" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="115" y="6318" width="110" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <UserObject label="<ul>
<li>Linux/container apps: <code>https://&lt;app-name&gt;.scm.azurewebsites.net/api/logs/docker/zip</code></li>
<li>Windows apps: <code>https://&lt;app-name&gt;.scm.azurewebsites.net/api/dump</code></li>
</ul>" link="<ul>
<li>Linux/container apps: <code>https://&lt;app-name&gt;.scm.azurewebsites.net/api/logs/docker/zip</code></li>
<li>Windows apps: <code>https://&lt;app-name&gt;.scm.azurewebsites.net/api/dump</code></li>
</ul>" id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-28"> <mxCell style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="20" y="6380" width="560" height="140" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> </UserObject> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-29" value="Certificate" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="130" y="6608" width="80" height="30" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-30" value="A certificate uploaded into an app is stored in a deployment unit that 
is bound to the app service plan's resource group and region combination
 (internally called a <em>webspace</em>). This makes the certificate accessible to other apps in the same resource group and region combination." style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="10" y="6670" width="560" height="80" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="P2O7nMcZ1-jrNbi8egKH-31" value="<p>The free <strong>App Service managed certificate</strong> and the <strong>App Service certificate</strong>
 already satisfy the requirements of App Service. If you want to use a 
private certificate in App Service, your certificate must meet the 
following requirements:</p>
<ul>
<li>Exported as a password-protected PFX file, encrypted using triple DES.</li>
<li>Contains private key at least 2048 bits long.</li>
<li>Contains all intermediate certificates and the root certificate in the certificate chain.</li>
</ul>" style="text;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;" vertex="1" parent="1"> <mxGeometry x="10" y="6764" width="510" height="250" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> </root> </mxGraphModel> </diagram> </mxfile>

ul.li:
Shared compute: Free and Shared,
the two base tiers, runs an app on the same Azure VM as other App
Service apps, including apps of other customers. These tiers allocate
CPU quotas to each app that runs on the shared resources, and the
resources can't scale out.

Dedicated compute: The Basic, Standard, Premium, PremiumV2, and PremiumV3
tiers run apps on dedicated Azure VMs. Only apps in the same App
Service plan share the same compute resources. The higher the tier, the
more VM instances are available to you for scale-out.

Isolated: The Isolated and IsolatedV2
tiers run dedicated Azure VMs on dedicated Azure Virtual Networks. It
provides network isolation on top of compute isolation to your apps. It
provides the maximum scale-out capabilities.

ul.li:
Azure DevOps Services: You can push your code to
Azure DevOps Services, build your code in the cloud, run the tests,
generate a release from the code, and finally, push your code to an
Azure Web App.

GitHub: Azure supports automated deployment
directly from GitHub. When you connect your GitHub repository to Azure
for automated deployment, any changes you push to your production branch
on GitHub are automatically deployed for you.
Bitbucket: With its similarities to GitHub, you can configure an automated deployment with Bitbucket.

ul.li:
Git: App Service web apps feature a Git URL that
you can add as a remote repository. Pushing to the remote repository
deploys your app.

CLI: webapp up is a feature of the az command-line interface that packages your app and deploys it. Unlike other deployment methods, az webapp up can create a new App Service web app for you if you haven't already created one.
Zip deploy: Use curl or a similar HTTP utility to send a ZIP of your application files to App Service.
FTP/S: FTP or FTPS is a traditional way of pushing your code to many hosting environments, including App Service.

div.div:
Whenever possible, use deployment slots when deploying a new production
build. When using a Standard App Service Plan tier or better, you can
deploy your app to a staging environment and then swap your staging and
production slots. The swap operation warms up the necessary worker
instances to match your production scale, thus eliminating downtime.

div.p:
For custom containers from Azure Container Registry or other
container registries, deploy the image into a staging slot and swap into
production to prevent downtime. The automation is more complex than
code deployment because you must push the image to a container registry
and update the image tag on the webapp.

ul.li:
Build and tag the image: As part of the build
pipeline, tag the image with the git commit ID, timestamp, or other
identifiable information. It’s best not to use the default “latest” tag.
Otherwise, it’s difficult to trace back what code is currently
deployed, which makes debugging far more difficult.

Push the tagged image: Once the image is built and
tagged, the pipeline pushes the image to our container registry. In the
next step, the deployment slot will pull the tagged image from the
container registry.
Update the deployment slot with the new image tag: When this property is updated, the site will automatically restart and pull the new container image.

div.p:
The authentication flow is the same for all providers, but differs
depending on whether you want to sign in with the provider's SDK.

li.p:
Without provider SDK: The application delegates federated sign-in
to App Service. This delegation is typically the case with browser
apps, which can present the provider's login page to the user. The
server code manages the sign-in process and is referred to as server-directed flow or server flow.

With provider SDK: The application signs users in to the provider
manually and then submits the authentication token to App Service for
validation. This is typically the case with browser-less apps, which
can't present the provider's sign-in page to the user. The application
code manages the sign-in process and is referred to as client-directed flow or client flow.
This applies to REST APIs, Azure Functions, JavaScript browser clients,
and native mobile apps that sign users in using the provider's SDK.

switch.text: The authentication flow is the same for all providers, but differs...

div.p:
The worker VMs are broken down in large part by the App Service
plans. The Free, Shared, Basic, Standard, and Premium plans all use the
same worker VM type. The PremiumV2 plan uses another VM type. PremiumV3
uses yet another VM type. When you change the VM family, you get a
different set of outbound addresses.

There are many addresses that are used for outbound calls. The
outbound addresses used by your app for making outbound calls are listed
in the properties for your app. These addresses are shared by all the
apps running on the same worker VM family in the App Service deployment.
If you want to see all the addresses that your app might use in a scale
unit, there's a property called possibleOutboundIpAddresses that lists them.

a.xlink:href:
https://app.diagrams.net/

or Windows apps, you can customize the IIS handler mappings and virtual applications and directories.

Handler mappings let you add custom script processors to handle requests for specific file extensions. To add a custom handler, select New handler mapping. Configure the handler as follows:

  • Extension: The file extension you want to handle, such as *.php or handler.fcgi.
  • Script processor: The absolute path of the script processor. Requests to files that match the file extension are processed by the script processor. Use the path D:\home\site\wwwroot to refer to your app's root directory.
  • Arguments: Optional command-line arguments for the script processor.

div.p:
ou can add custom storage for your containerized app. Containerized
apps include all Linux apps and also the Windows and Linux custom
containers running on App Service. Select New Azure Storage Mount and configure your custom storage as follows:

ul.li: Name: The display name.
Configuration options: Basic or Advanced. Select Basic if the storage account isn't using service endpoints, private endpoints, or Azure Key Vault. Otherwise, select Advanced.
Storage accounts: The storage account with the container you want.
Storage type: Azure Blobs or Azure Files. Windows container apps only support Azure Files. Azure Blobs only supports read-only access.
Storage container: For basic configuration, the container you want.
Share name: For advanced configuration, the file share name.
Access key: For advanced configuration, the access key.
Mount path: The absolute path in your container to mount the custom storage.
Deployment slot setting: When checked, the storage mount settings also apply to deployment slots.

div.div:
Logs messages generated by your application code. The messages are
generated by the web framework you choose, or from your application code
directly using the standard logging pattern of your language. Each
message is assigned one of the following categories: Critical, Error, Warning, Info, Debug, and Trace.

Copies of the .html error pages that would have been sent to
the client browser. For security reasons, detailed error pages shouldn't
be sent to clients in production, but App Service can save the error
page each time an application error occurs that has HTTP code 400 or
greater.

div.div:
A certificate uploaded into an app is stored in a deployment unit that
is bound to the app service plan's resource group and region combination
(internally called a webspace). This makes the certificate accessible to other apps in the same resource group and region combination.

div.p:
The free App Service managed certificate and the App Service certificate
already satisfy the requirements of App Service. If you want to use a
private certificate in App Service, your certificate must meet the
following requirements:

ul.li: Exported as a password-protected PFX file, encrypted using triple DES.
Contains private key at least 2048 bits long.
Contains all intermediate certificates and the root certificate in the certificate chain.
